sentences.sentence: In the afternoon the next day, the two elder Miss Bennets were able to find a way to be alone together for half an hour.
Elizabeth instantly made use of the opportunity to question her.
“Did Lydia say anything to anyone before she left?”
“Colonel Forster brought with him the note she wrote to his wife, for us to see.”
Jane then took it from her note-book and gave it to Elizabeth.
These were the contents:
MY DEAR HARRIET,
You will laugh when you find out where I have gone.
I cannot help laughing myself at your surprise tomorrow morning, when you discover I am missing.
I am going to Scotland.
If you cannot guess with whom, I will think you are a fool, because there is only one man in the world whom I love.
You do not need to tell those at Longbourn I have left, because it will surprise them even more, when I write to them and sign my name ‘Lydia Wickham.’ Good-bye.
Give my love to Colonel Forster.
I hope you will give a toast to our good journey.
Your affectionate( 深情的 ) friend,
LYDIA BENNET.
“Oh! Thoughtless, thoughtless Lydia!” cried Elizabeth when she had finished it.
“What a letter this is, to be written at such a moment! But at least it shows that she was serious about marrying Wickham.
My poor father! How awfully he must have felt!”
All of Meryton now seemed eager to accuse( 控诉 ) Wickham of every evil( 罪恶 ), when just three months before, they had spoken of him as if he were an angel( 天使 ) from heaven.
It was claimed that he was in debt to every business in town.
Everybody confirmed( 认定 ) that he was the wickedest( 最坏的 ) young man in the world, and everybody began to realize that they had always distrusted( 不信任 ) the appearance of his goodness.
Every day at Longbourn was now filled with( 充斥 ) anxiety.
The most anxious part of each day was when the mail was expected.
Through letters, whatever good or bad news that could be told was communicated.
Every new day was expected to bring some news of importance.
They soon received a letter from Colonel Forster, but he had nothing helpful to say.
It was not known whether Wickham had kept up a single relationship with any of his old acquaintances( 熟人 ), and considering how much he was in debt to so many,
he had very good reasons for staying hidden.
Colonel Forster believed that he was more than a thousand pounds in debt at Brighton.
The next letter they received was from Mr. Gardiner, who told them that they could expect their father to come home on the following day, which was Saturday.
When Mr. Bennet arrived, he appeared as calm as he usually did, and said as little as he had ever been in the habit of saying.
He especially did not mention anything about Lydia or Wickham, and it took some time before his daughters were brave enough to speak of it.
It was not until the afternoon, when he had joined them at tea, that Elizabeth dared to bring up the subject.
After briefly expressing her sorrow for what he must have suffered, he replied, “Do not speak of that.
Who should suffer except for myself? It is my own fault, and I ought to feel the pain of it.”
“You should not be too hard on yourself,” replied Elizabeth.
“No, Lizzy, let me for once in my life feel how much I have been to blame.
I am not afraid of being overcome by the feeling—it will pass away soon enough.
I want you to know that I do not resent( 埋怨 ) you at all for being correct in your advice to me last May.
Considering what has happened, I believe that shows great generosity on my part.”
Two days after Mr. Bennet’s return, as Jane and Elizabeth were walking together in the garden behind the house, they saw the housekeeper( 管家 ) coming toward them.
“Please excuse me, madam( 女士 ), for interrupting you,” she said to Miss Bennet,
“I was hoping you might have heard some good news from town, so I took the chance of coming to ask.”
“What do you mean? We have heard nothing from town.”
“Dear madam( 女士 ),” cried the housekeeper( 管家 ), with great surprise,
“don’t you know that an express has come for Mr. Bennet from Mr. Gardiner? He was just here half an hour ago, and master has received a letter.”
Upon hearing this information, they ran across the lawn( 草坪 ) toward their father, who was making his way with determination toward a small group of trees on one side of the lawn( 草坪 ).
“Oh, papa( 爸爸 ), what news—what news? Have you heard from my uncle?”
“Yes, I have had a letter from him by express.”
“Well, and what news does it bring—good or bad?”
“What good can be expected?” he said, taking the letter from his pocket.
“But perhaps you would like to read it.”
Elizabeth impatiently( 迫不及待地 ) took it from his hand.
“Read it aloud,” said their father, “for I almost do not know myself what it is about.”
Gracechurch Street, Monday
August 2.
MY DEAR BROTHER,
I am happy to be able to send you some news about my niece.
I hope that, on the whole, it may give you some satisfaction.
Soon after Elizabeth left us, I was fortunate enough to find out where Lydia was in London.
I will not mention the details( 细节 ) until we meet.
It is enough to tell you that they have been found.
I have seen them both—
“Then it is as I had hoped,” cried Jane, “they have gotten married!”
Elizabeth read on:
I have seen them both.
They are not married, and it does not seem that there was ever any intention that they would be.
However, if you are willing to agree to the arrangements which I have dared to make on your behalf( 代表 ), I hope it will not be long before they are married.
All that is required for you to do is, to promise your daughter that she will receive her equal share of the five thousand pounds she was promised to inherit( 继承 ).
You must also promise to give her, while you are still alive, one hundred pounds per year.
If, as I hope, you agree to these terms and allow me to act on your behalf( 代表 ), I will tell my lawyer to prepare the necessary legal papers.
Please reply as soon as you can, I will write again as soon as anything more has been decided.
YOURS, EDW. GARDINER.

article_info.previous: Mr. Darcy阻止了Elizabeth，并让仆人们去找她舅舅和舅母，Elizabeth又急又气，边哭边向Mr. Darcy讲述了事情的起因经过，回到家后Jane却没有得到任何新消息，一家人的心情都蒙上了一层阴影。
article_info.share_words: Everybody confirmed that he was the wickedest young man in the world, and everybody began to realize that they had always distrusted the appearance of his goodness.

question.en: Who did Lydia write to before she left?

options.cn: 她给Colonel Forster的妻子写了一封短信。
options.en: She wrote a note to Colonel Forster's wife.

analysis: 文中对话中提到：“‘Did Lydia say anything to anyone before she left?’ ‘Colonel Forster brought with him the note she wrote to his wife, for us to see.’” 所以选C。

question.cn: 在Lydia的事情发生之后，Meryton的人们是如何看待Wickham的？
question.en: What did people of Meryton think of Wickham after this event?

options.en: They thought he was very evil.

options.cn: 他们认为他是一个天使。
options.en: They regarded him as an angel.

analysis: 文中提到：“All of Meryton now seemed eager to accuse Wickham of every evil, when just three months before, they had spoken of him as if he were an angel from heaven.” 所以选A。

question.cn: 信里面要求Mr. Bennt做什么？
question.en: What was Mr. Bennt required to do according to the letter?

options.cn: 为Lydia和Wickham举行一场盛大的婚礼。
options.en: To hold a grand wedding for Lydia and Wickham.
To promise to give Lydia money.

options.cn: 为Wickham在教堂里找一份工作。
options.en: To give Wickham a job in the church.

analysis: 文中信里提到：“ All that is required for you to do is......You must also promise to give her, while you are still alive, one hundred pounds per year.” 所以选B。
